title: How to Make Potato Chips Using Safflower Oil

steps.headline: Scrub the potatoes before cooking.
steps.description: Remove any dirt from the skin. Cut out any blemishes.

steps.headline: Leave the skin on.
steps.description: You will be slicing the potatoes very thinly––you won’t need to peel unless you have a total aversion to potato skin.

steps.headline: Slice the potatoes.
steps.description: You can hand slice the potatoes or use a mandolin. The mandolin will produce the most even results. Keep the mandolin guard in place when using this device. If not used properly, it can slice fingers too. Slice potatoes using the 1.33 setting for crisp but hearty chips.

steps.headline: Place the sliced potatoes in a bowl filled with cold water so that the potato slices stay fresh.
steps.description: Once all the potatoes have been sliced, drain the bowl and rinse the potatoes. Dry the slices on a clean towel and roll pre-cooked chips up until you're ready to cook them.

steps.headline: Heat the safflower oil to 350ºF/180ºC in a suitable pot.
steps.description: Use a large pot and only fill it halfway with the oil, to avoid splatters. Don’t drop chips into the pot until you know the oil has reached 350ºF/180ºC. If you drop the chips in too soon, they could become soggy as they cook instead of crisp.

steps.headline: Fry the chips in the heated oil for one to two minutes.
Transfer the cooked chips to a dish coated with paper towels.

text:
Scrub the potatoes before cooking. Remove any dirt from the skin. Cut out any blemishes. Leave the skin on. You will be slicing the potatoes very thinly––you won’t need to peel unless you have a total aversion to potato skin. Slice the potatoes. You can hand slice the potatoes or use a mandolin. The mandolin will produce the most even results. Keep the mandolin guard in place when using this device. If not used properly, it can slice fingers too. Slice potatoes using the 1.33 setting for crisp but hearty chips. Place the sliced potatoes in a bowl filled with cold water so that the potato slices stay fresh. Once all the potatoes have been sliced, drain the bowl and rinse the potatoes. Dry the slices on a clean towel and roll pre-cooked chips up until you're ready to cook them. Heat the safflower oil to 350ºF/180ºC in a suitable pot. Use a large pot and only fill it halfway with the oil, to avoid splatters. Don’t drop chips into the pot until you know the oil has reached 350ºF/180ºC. If you drop the chips in too soon, they could become soggy as they cook instead of crisp. Fry the chips in the heated oil for one to two minutes. Turn the chips after they’ve been in the oil for over 30 seconds, to brown each side. Only drop two or three chips into the pot of oil at a time (depending on the size pot you are using). You want each chip to have room to fry and not stick to each other. The amount you can add may vary depending on the size of the pot you're using; just be sure to keep the frying chips separated. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Make-Homemade-Potato-Chips-Using-Safflower-Oil-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Homemade-Potato-Chips-Using-Safflower-Oil-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/d/df/Make-Homemade-Potato-Chips-Using-Safflower-Oil-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/aid2351162-v4-728px-Make-Homemade-Potato-Chips-Using-Safflower-Oil-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"486","licensing":"
